Robin Wright is so damn good at playing this character that I really wish they had found a better way to showcase her talents. House of Cards was a great show that turned into a good one. This final season is good but could have been great.
Intense, compressed storytelling, crackling with twists and turns...
The series is superficial trash, yes, but lovingly polished trash. I couldn't stop watching.
I’ll also say that I didn’t see the twist coming, which I suppose makes Stay Close a successful Coben series.
This series is good news for for Anglophiles who want to see something a bit different from the usual British crime drama.
An entertaining drama full of flirting, thrills and familiar faces...

Stay Close benefits from fine performances and a story that gives just enough clues in the first episode to keep viewers intrigued and - more importantly - not frustrated with purposely obtuse writing.
A perfect summer evening binge-watch.
Character depth is created by harried reactions, the mood is uniformly ominous. It's not subtle, but it can be effective.

The trouble with Stay Close is that it's too familiar. Despite the plethora of unexpected twists, this series manages to feel identical to every other crime drama that's been thrown out in recent years, and not a particularly great one at that.
See you for the next episode, plus the six after that - and there's no point pretending otherwise.

"Stay Close" builds its puzzle slowly, through subliminal editing of past violence and through the silences in what the characters don't say to each other - empty spaces that invite us to imagine what happened to these people all those years ago.

But even by the well-established standards of these things, Stay Close is particularly bonkers, a lightning-fast, highly binge-able thriller that works mostly by sensory overload and never quite giving a straight answer. Happy New Year!
Stay Close is compelling in the way that makes you want to keep going with it, if not compelling in the way that you'd remember it in much detail a few months down the line

Show: How to Get Away With Murder
Review: It was melodramatic and more than a little manipulative -- descriptions that have applied to the show from the beginning, but which were more tolerable before the novelty of its serialized mystery format wore off.

Show: How to Get Away With Murder
Review: We're only one episode into How to Get Away With Murder's final season, and I'm already very worried about Annalise Keating.

Show: How to Get Away With Murder
Review: If Viola Davis is planning on running an Emmy campaign for her final season in this career-changing role, this is a hell of a start.

Show: How to Get Away With Murder
Review: t's a thrilling beginning, but will How To Get Away With Murder fall into its same old pattern of peaking too soon and then crumbling under the weight of its intentionally convoluted approach to mystery-building?

Show: How to Get Away With Murder
Review: It wouldn't be a shocking conclusion to see Annalise die by the series finale, but a closed casket and no sightings of any of her "people" has my interest piqued.
It's a pity that the series that was once an addictive madness, it now conforms to being simply madness. [Full review in Spanish]
By its new fifth season, Élite finally arrives at the point where it can no longer pull off its gimmicks.
A big cult hit, it’s no masterpiece but is one of those oddly satisfying, binge-worthy curiosities.
Its campy, its sexy, and its fun to watch. For the most part, Elite ticks all of the boxes that you want it to, and thats all that matters in the end.
I think the relationship between Gus and Big Man overrules any other issues I may have had with the show, and the performances of both actors are stellar.

Like the best family productions, Sweet Tooth evokes the child in the adult and the adult in the child, not pandering to youngsters with empty gestures nor implying crusty oldies cannot be filled with wonder.
Sweet Tooth ends up resembling a fairy tale of sorts, with lush visuals and colors that pop, despite all the death and destruction on the edges.
When the show devolves into mystery and action, it loses much of what makes it unique -- but at least Gus is still there to help you make it through.
It's the show that the stuck-at-home-too-long audience needs right now, and it's a big, comic-book-loving blanket of a series.

Sweet Tooth is, by and large, a charming show anchored by a lovable protagonist. Making good use of its extensive budget, it works equally well for kids and adult audiences, adding a heartwarming and whimsical tone to a typically grim genre.
It makes our reality a tad more palatable. It provides a form of emotional hospice, allowing the viewers to revel in the show's dreamlike aura.
A charming coming-of-age story wrapped in postapocalyptic tragedy, Sweet Tooth manages to address its horrific circumstances with tenderness and warmth.
You may be wondering what Netflix were thinking by releasing such a show during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, but the series is a beacon of light during these dark times.
The series is a mix of whimsical, campy and reality which seems like an odd combination on paper, but works well for the story.

Young Christian makes a star-making turn as Gus, brilliantly conveying the lead character's daring streak, his innocence and his determination, all the while measuring up to his co-star Nonso in talent, albeit not in stature.
It seems unfair to call a drama about a ruined world a mess, but this feels, quite deliberately, all over the place.
Visually striking and grippingly plotted up to a cliffhanger of a season finale, Sweet Tooth is suspenseful, thoughtful, and timely in ways that couldn't have been planned.
It is both mystifying and somehow fitting that one of the more cogent commentaries on our current messy mix of pandemics and politics revolves around a boy with antlers growing out of his head.
It's a sweet story, full of hope and good vibes, set against an all too familiar genre that is dark and gloomy.

In eight episodes, the series has managed to tell a compelling and meaningful story that seems prophetic in certain ways to our current world. But, as the filmmakers have coined it as a descriptive phrase, it is a storybook dystopia.
I'm enjoying the message of kindness and the incredible acting by the main character Gus, and Big Man (Nonso Anozie), I highly recommend this series which will be renewed for another season
Whether Sweet Tooth can travel the same surprise path to stardom remains to be seen, but it's at least nice to have a new show worth following as we enter another summer...
he discarded darker elements of the source material give the saga a softer edge, creating something more palpable for viewers to understand. The end result is an elegant and touching hero's journey.
The Netflix adaptation of Jeff Lemire's comic manages to powerfully convey both the heart and the horror of its titular character's saga.
As far as end-of-the-world narratives go, Fury Road this isn't. Despite its apocalyptic premise, the show is weirdly sweet and family-friendly. Not great, exactly, but compelling in its own way.
Brilliant. You're horrified but you're also giddy because this fable mixed with a thriller is so well done.
Combining sci-fi with fantasy, it's an intriguing post-apocalyptic tale, one that tugs at your heart.
Sweet Tooth feels awfully familiar at first, and then goes places that surprise and delight.

After so many months without leaving home for fear of the virus, watching Sweet Tooth could be a good idea: it is a loving hug that rests on ideas about tolerance, solidarity and empathy. [Full Review in Spanish]
Sweet Tooth presents a terrifying and desperate situation without this closing the possibility of a bright future. [Full Review in Spanish]
Sweet Tooth is especially compelling as many of us move toward some form of post-pandemic normalcy, raising questions about what new world awaits us after such tremendous, collective loss.
My heart had sunk: not another dystopia/fantasy/gothic kids' tale gussied up to con adults into watching two-and-a-bit episodes? But it's really rather lovely.
Sweet Tooth is an earnest adaptation elevated by strong characters, inspired performances, and the promise of more answers - and more questions - in its inevitable sophomore season.
The series perfectly demonstrates how to tell several parallel stories and at the same time build a mythology around a cataclysmic event. [Full review in Spanish]

Its anchored by a terrific performance from Convery, who infuses Gus with childlike wonder and a deep well of empathy. Anozie also shines as Jep, and the series does a great job of toeing the line between being sweet and cynical.
There is a great deal of jeopardy along the way, but the scenes always come back to something reassuring, and there is no gore.

Sweet Tooth brings something strange and heartfelt to the ongoing slew of apocalyptic stories hitting the big and small screens... an excellent fantasy about facing a world suddenly changing in ways where one catastrophe impacts every facet of life.

Weaving together three disparate plots that eventually intersect, the show offers three different visions of life after a devastating pandemic, each shaped by how its characters react to the end of the world.
Packages real-world terrors in a fashion that at once confronts them honestly and contextualizes them in a way that's friendly for young teen viewers.
It's a gentle, delightful series that has a vein of tragedy running through it but it's not overwhelmingly dark.
The longer we spend in Gus's world the more we're encouraged to see our own within it. This might be a fantasy, but it isn't necessarily escapist.
Plague aftershock as entertainment seems preposterous right about now, but when transformed by the weirdo extremes of "Sweet Tooth's" universe, the subject becomes a post-apocalyptic joyride.
It is either warmly eccentric or hysterically crazy, perfect entertainment or a horrifying attempt to parlay the pandemic into a commercially palatable mashup.
It's got a great set-up... there's less of an overall arc, and it's more of a show of discovery for the characters involved.
Thanks to an appealing young star, a flashback-heavy structure, reassuring narration and a bright aesthetic, "Sweet" achieves the tricky art of a high-concept, family-friendly fantasy series.
"Sweet Tooth" may not offer a full meal, but sometimes all you need is a good piece of chocolate.
Sweet Tooth is fascinating, charming, and it beautifully conveys a feeling of childlike wonder.
Good performances and an adaptation that grounds things into some sort of reality saves the show from eye-rolling preciousness.
The show turns Jeff Lemire's lurid comic into a childlike adventure, but it loses the complexity, the ugliness, and the raw emotion that made the saga so rich in the first place.

For the right kind of kid, Sweet Tooth might make for good family viewing; there is enough in the way of complication here to keep parents intrigued without sending the show spinning down into pure absurdity for its own sake.
Welcome to your long winter weekend addiction.
A lot of really great cinematography and fight scenes and visuals... A breath of fresh air.
Sweet Tooth is poised to be the latest big budget smash hit fantasy series for Netflix, delivering a warm and epic adventure.
Sweet Tooth mixes its heartfelt nature with this dark premise, and it ultimately creates one of the more magical experiences of the year. This has the potential to be a massive series.
Despite the on-the-nose elements of the show's pandemic portrayal, Sweet Tooth is a series worth your time and emotional energy.

The costumes, sets, and action scenes follow suit; all of them work in tandem to build an impressive, hard-to-describe tone, which somehow is a bullseye that hits family-friendly, high fantasy, comic book movie, and survival thriller all at once.
With a winning (and occasionally brutal) approach to its darkly fantastical imaginings, Sweet Tooth find a nice balance between its sugary and bitter elements.
An open letter to Netflix - please do not cancel this. Sweet Tooth deserves to stay. Let it breathe.

The inaugural season only chronicles part of Gus and Jepperd's journey, but what a mark it leaves. This adaptation slowly worms its way into your heart and threatens to rip it out through awe, wonder, and character-driven emotional depth.
Sweet Tooth's messages of hope and resilience, even in the darkest moments, is perfectly timed, giving us a buoyant fable for an uncertain age.

Emotionally and geographically, this is a show with real epic scope, and it earns the laughter and occasional tears that it wrings from the audience thanks to a real and unquestionable, well, sweetness.
Some pretty heady ideas here for a kids show, but then family entertainment, like so many things in 2021, is evolving in ways that we haven't seen before.
A very well done show that keeps what made the comic special but makes it more mainstream. The locations are incredible and the cast is amazing. Definitely worth watching.

Whether Gus and friends are having scary adventures or fun ones, those parts of Sweet Tooth are full of life, and as exciting or tense as needed. The show can be hit or miss, though, when it moves away from Gus.
Despite the dark premise of this series, it is heartfelt, fun, and its lead is as sweet as the title suggests.
The performances are strong throughout -- Anozie is particularly remarkable -- but it's the consistently inventive writing and robust filmmaking that makes the project stand out.
Sweet Tooth is a success. It's a near-perfect adaptation. It's strong when it comes to effects work, acting, and story.
Sweet Tooth is an absolute joy to behold, brimming with love, hope, beauty, and, well, sweet treats.

Sweet Tooth is a wholly enjoyable, family-friendly comic book TV series that features amazing performances from its leads, and sets the stage for future stories in a way that's left us anxious to return to this weird, charming world.
Sweet Tooth is a well-rounded epic that has the potential to be a long-running success for Netflix that will keep audiences entertained for seasons to come.
Fittingly switching between sweetness and bite, Sweet Tooth is a children's fable fit for grown-ups.

The chemistry between Convery and Anozie keeps the story ticking along. The central partnership between these two is the key selling point of the show, bringing a sense of sweetness and sentiment that buoys the occasionally dark subject matter.

Frankly, Sweet Tooth is premiering at the right time. Even though some may roll their eyes at a story that kicks off with a pandemic and a lingering virus threat, we can all relate to this material in some way. It's the hope that sticks with you.
A dark and gritty story wrapped in a visually stunning bow, offering messages of nature thriving, and hope for humankind.
Featuring a beautiful central dynamic and surprisingly optimistic message, Sweet Tooth breathes new life into the often dark post-apocalyptic genre.
In a world full of post-apocalyptic stories, Sweet Tooth flips the genre on its head with gorgeous storybook visuals and a rousing message of hope. This show an absolute must-see.
Christian Convery as Gus is adorable, and his relationship with Nonso as Big Man is very sweet... Their adventure has me hyped for the inevitable second season.

What the series creators, fully consciously of it or not, do show is a country ruled by vehemently anti-democratic and authoritarian cliques, none of whom would exhibit the slightest qualms about establishing openly dictatorial rule.

Madden plays Budd like a time bomb poised to detonate, revealing a man scarred by his wartime experiences. Hawes is excellent as the hawkish politician and Mercurio keeps the twists coming through to the finale.
She's older, upper class, English, and female; he's younger, working class, Scottish, and male. There's 50 shades of "ma'am" in the way he addresses her.

While Bodyguard is being billed as a thriller, at its core it's that old favourite of the British isles, the police procedural - and crucially, even when it's just going through the procedures, it stays engaging.
Bodyguard adds to a long and damaging media trend of depicting brown people as terrorists.
Six hours of a magnificent police drama. [Full Review in Spanish]
The more ridiculous and far-fetched Bodyguard becomes, the more I am gripped.
A taut limited series from the UK that will curl your hair; it is INTENSE. If you haven't seen it, hold a day to devote to six full length episodes on Netflix and expect to be deeply spooked.
Unfortunately, full of filler where there should be thriller, Bodyguard just can't get the job done, literally or figuratively.

The story takes wild, violent leaps amid myriad conspiracies, leading to a crazy, nail-biting climax that is both preposterous and wholly satisfying. Some binges feel like a slog. Bodyguard is more of a race, well worth the run.
The intense BBC drama didn't disappoint as it went out all guns blazing.
This has been a brilliant, compulsive, five-star mind trip of a series.

The result is a fatally broken series - it starts very well and goes off the rails in its last episodes - but it is blatantly visible that it offers the same discourse as the cinema of the 70s: the institutions are rotten. [Full Review in Spanish]
After a few chapters, Bodyguard does something that is as bold as it is absurd, changing all the pieces of the game, but losing all cohesion. [Full review in Spanish]

Pure, can't-take-your-eyes away entertainment that's bound to have you saying "just one more episode before bed." This is sterling television, a well-crafted crime thriller, which is what the BBC does best.
It's had a tremendous critical reception... and virtually everyone who's mentioned it to me says it's brilliant. The opening definitely was; the rest of the episode wasn't quite at that level.
It's two things at once - the list of who did what and the reminder of what happened - and it feels nicely succinct. Like everything else about "Bodyguard," including its hero, the opening is taut.
The denouement is far too wordy and protracted, albeit peppered with some genuinely nail-biting moments. The show has earned your patience by this point, though, so you will gladly watch to the end.
Suspenseful political crime show is smart but violent.
In only six chapters, this British series is capable of enthusing you, engaging you and then shortly after, turning into a light disappointment. [Full Review in Spanish]
A shot of adrenaline. A reminder of how engaging and engrossing the medium of telly can be.
The world of Bodyguard is all cynical shades of gray, where the best you can hope for is just to survive.
It's a failed opportunity, and the result is a story that offers tantalizing threads of complexity, only to cut them all off right as they start combining into something truly innovative.
After watching the entire series in one six-hour sitting, I get it. It made my heart race. It made me sweaty. I felt at times flush and lightheaded. And that was just Keeley Hawes.
The series is ultimately Madden's, who handily proves he's capable of much, much more than brooding as King in the North.
It helps that Madden looks like an old-fashioned action hero, but can embody the ideals of one, too, albeit with conflict and angst that feel distinctly contemporary.

The way these stories zero in on the morally compromised institutions responsible for individual suffering screams 2018...[Bodyguard] subverts thriller tropes just often enough to earn its reliance on them.

Bodyguard is a perfectly calibrated thriller that cleverly builds up the tension so you're always questioning what you see and hear, puzzling over everyone's motivations and real loyalties, and to hook you from beginning to end.
Bodyguard remains a gripping and thoroughly entertaining adventure that's emotionally deft, but that clumsy ending dims its overall excellence.
Those are minor gripes given the thrill factor and how easily Bodyguard grabs your attention and doesn't relinquish it.
As Budd, Richard Madden is astonishing. His sweet good looks could have worked against the gravity of his role, but instead they give his tortured psychology a sympathetic appeal.
Netflix's Bodyguard delivers a thrilling first season, proving why it's the UK's most-watched drama of 2018 so far.
Bodyguard could unfold as a boilerplate political thriller, but the series defies expectations at every twist and turn-almost.
The end result is an engaging series that walks a very fine line between grounded political thriller and something far more outlandish.
Bodyguard is a tense, tightly plotted thrill ride that makes almost no false moves.
Mercurio and director Thomas Vincent grasp the viewer like a stressball in the palm of a hand. Squeeze, release, repeat.
Madden's face is the kind of canvas that you want to watch for clues.
Stream it - it's one of the best first episodes we've seen all year, and it feels like the wild ride of Bodyguard is just getting started.
There may be nothing groundbreaking about Bodyguard, but it's easy to see why it's breaking records. Like its politico-thriller forerunners, the show is taut entertainment for our time...

To watch Bodyguard's six episodes is to suspend disbelief and submit to its surprises. It helps not to expect too much more than that, particularly when it comes to the show's lavish employment of archetypes.
One nagging plot hole doesn't detract from the momentum, and it's almost uncanny how deftly the series shifts the weight of the viewer's suspicions without coming off too tricksy. Good stuff.
It can also be a blast, if you're all about the mystery and the forward momentum and your requirements for plausibility and psychological realism aren't high.
The key resolution is that despite all the nefarious men populating the series, women were actually always the biggest power players in this political thriller.
Bodyguard is bloody brilliant from the get-go. And if you watch, pay close attention to the terrorist who is tackled. It will be important later.
Even when Bodyguard does get a bit over the top, that same British flair for understatement prevents it from feeling as ridiculous as it might in other hands.
This enthralling thriller series should come with warnings about how anxiety-inducing it is, as well as how much you'll now want Richard Madden to play James Bond.
More concerned with being a good ride than exploring character or politics, the show is awash in a timely cynicism.
The action is well mounted and the tension tightly wound; it uncoils, when it does, with a satisfying snap.
Both juicy in its delving into character psychology and rippingly ready to tear up its playbook as it goes, it's a six-episode ride that demands, and rewards, a quick binge.

Bodyguard is a thriller first, and in respect to the elements that relate to the genre, the show masterfully excels. What makes it work is how well the show presents in the form of a slow-burn story despite moving at a rather quick stride.
[Bodyguard is] one of those crowd-pleasing thrillers that manages to be both cerebral and terrible, where characters constantly do dumb things that leave you howling at the screen.
Madden and Hawes have incredible chemistry, and like Madden, Hawes balances the public and private faces of her character with ease.
The plot makes up in symmetry what it may lack in believability.
[Mercurio] sprints the thin line between thrilling and tosh.
The scripts are so gripping and suspenseful, once you've watched one episode, it's hard not to become hooked.

Mercurio, the writer behind the gritty police procedural Line of Duty, has a way of bringing psychological complexity to the more outlandish pleasures of the thriller genre, and Bodyguard slaloms happily between the two.
Bodyguard...still might be the best thing Jed Mercurio has ever written.
Even though Bodyguard is sometimes wanting, you can't much argue with the power and tension of the central relationship.
Viewers are in for a bumpy ride, though a thrilling one too, I hope.
The action mesmerises, nearly stops you drawing breath.
Bodyguard starts frenetic and stays there.
I can't wait to see what happens next. However, I do wonder about some of the casting. Though Madden can be rather wooden, that doesn't matter a jot here.

In Bodyguard, Mercurio trains his eye and his nose for corruption on the corridors of power and, by the end of [the] opening episode, it was clear he has created something as dark and moreish as ever.
Bodyguard is an extremely successful production. Imagine it as a cross between The Thick of It and a Bond movie and you'll have the measure of it.
Besides the sharp scripting and deft direction, also key to hooking the audience here is Madden's rather revelatory performances.
All I can say is I already do not trust anyone in it - which is exactly what you want from a thriller.
Bodyguard is intelligent, psychological storytelling so gripping you'll have to remind yourself to breathe.
Already it's a wild, thrilling ride. One thing is clear: Bodyguard is heading nowhere obvious.
Richard Madden was spot-on as the inscrutable Budd.
It runs like explosive clockwork, and even when you know that the conversation has turned too damned quiet, the shock and awe of the "maybe gunfire" is irresistible.
Ed Helms' Nathan is back in season 2, ready to "de-center" himself as a white dude living in a town built on Native land. It's the best decision he — and the show itself — could have made.
This sophomore season from Peacock continues to make some brave choices.

Not only is Rutherford Falls an enjoyable watch, but the sitcom thoughtfully dissects American culture and centers Native stories. There’s no dearth of excellent television right now, but this heartwarming, funny, and boundary-breaking show is a must-see.

An endearing revisit to the world of Rutherford Falls and the Minishonka Nation. If you enjoy hot dog condiment fights, getting into the wrong funeral casket and burning toy babies while running a firefighter’s gauntlet, you’re in for a real treat.
A sweeter, steadier sophomore outing.
Rutherford Falls puts a much-needed twist on the sitcom formula, finding a perpetually clever sense of hilarity at nearly every turn.
A warm reunion with its characters to raise spirits in difficult times. [Full Review in Spanish]
An entertaining, sharply written episode about our times.
A fresh episode set during the age of social distancing provides welcome updates on Leslie, Ron and many, many other old friends.
The cast of "Parks and Rec" reunited for a coronavirus charity special. It was so good, and an undertaking that only this show could have pulled off. We pray no one else tries.
Nine times out of 10 -- really, 99 out of 100 -- TV revivals are a bad idea even under optimal production conditions. ... This was an exception to the rule

No one knows how to take lemons and make lemonade like Leslie Knope, and that's definitely what A Parks and Recreation Special feels like -- an unexpected silver lining to a dark cloud. Was it necessary? No. Was it enjoyable? Heck yeah.

Parks and Recreation returned to make us smile, and the special definitely hit us in the heart. We salute you, Leslie Knope, and your extended friend family, and we thank you for your help in this troubling situation.
Parks and Rec delivered to its fans what the show is famous for: Hope, sweetness, enthusiasm, and light comedy.
The entire event was a love letter to the series, and its closing moments were heartfelt enough to get any Parks and Rec fan in their feelings.
Watching the reunion special, I found I could still enjoy its bighearted comedy, albeit less as optimistic realism and more as utopian science fiction.
Parks and Recreation managed to raft a reunion special that, while satisfying on a base level, also speaks directly to the challenges we're facing today.
There are no new resolutions needed. Instead, It's meant to exemplify the very core of Leslie and the show itself: doing good.
Rather than pure escapism or cringe-worthy seriousness, the Parks and Rec writers created something that feels urgent without being self-important, and sweet without being saccharine.
It was impossible to dislike - even if it was inescapably melancholy.
Groundbreaking or not, we need that warmth and that hope now more than ever and, with a characteristically good cause, "A Parks and Recreation Special" more than delivered.

"A Parks and Recreation Special" doesn't need my charitable pass because it's a delight. Given the technical limitations and difficult circumstances, the Parks team is able to create something that feels like a satisfying reunion.
It was everything fans of the sweet, hopeful and hilarious series could have hoped for in this time of great need.
Well, I cried, of course. But it was the nice kind of crying. Maybe I even needed it. And hey, sometimes that's all you can ask for from a visit with old friends.

It's fun. I loved it. Spending 30 minutes visiting these fake characters who I haven't seen in five years ranked right up there with many of my Zoom calls to friends and family who I haven't seen in what feels like five years.

Against all odds, though, A Parks and Recreation Special is a genuine return from one of the best TV series ever made. In a strange way, the sitcom's faux-documentary structure lends itself well to the videoconferencing conceit.
Thanks, everyone. We needed this.
The Parks and Rec special was a lot of fun as an experiment. I don't want to see it become the new normal.

A Parks and Recreation Special landed the same way that a Zoom call with high school classmates or former co-workers from a decade ago does. It made us feel like we were reconnecting with old friends.
This made for a better kind of very special episode. "Parks" didn't return for half an hour to tell us what to think; it helped us feel what we feel.
"A Parks and Recreation Special" is one nice surprise after another, and I was glad to have each be, you know, surprising.
Fortunately, the one-off special doesn't disappoint, as the cast and crew did an amazing job when it comes to picking up where things let off.
Wonderful cast; great locale; entertaining script. Hate to see this show close down.

It will be interesting to see how and when the show begins to address the finality of things, and whether or not Longmire plans go out big or if it will stay business as usual for the sheriff of Absaroka County.

"Everybody Dies" is a failure of ambition, a frustratingly slapdash affair that tries to hide its lack of ideas behind the usual forced theatrics, reeking of a fan-fiction-like conviction in its own awesomeness. And it sucked. Hard.
Thanks for the enjoyable ride, House. I'll miss your endless sarcastic wit, your perfect stubble and your brutal honesty.
The show still offers something you don't find elsewhere on network TV: a mad, sad scientist who almost certainly does not have a heart of gold.
House had, in its final seasons, become a rather sentimental show anyway. A fitting ending, in other words.
House snapped back to form this season and delivered a solid suite of farewell episodes.

Despite containing some thematic similarities to the aforementioned installments, all of the plots presented center around the human side of House, rather than the all-too-familiar unrelenting diagnostician.
You really have to hand it to the team, as they've crafted a flawed, yet hugely satisfying series ender that wraps things up where needed while leaving enough open for fans to ponder.
House may be as predictable as a three-frame Peanuts cartoon; but low on their own supply after a mere eight seasons? Not a bit of it.
A fitting finale and swan song for House, even if one hasn't kept up with the series' eight-year run.
The sudden introduction of suicidal thoughts could easily play as soapy...But House has always been a character with one foot in the self-inflicted grave.
This once-venerable hit is suffering from a serious case of been-there-itis.
"Everybody Dies" was as close to a perfect House finale as I could possible imagine, a fabulous hour of television that cut straight to the heart of what House has always been about.
Credit Laurie for making such an unlikable character likable, if not completely adorable.
The overwhelming majority of The Affair's episodes are directed by men, making it difficult to push beyond the male gaze.
No TV series has dropped the viewer in the middle of narrative discord quite so effectively, as each hour split its perspective among different characters.
The soapy plot is getting ridiculously bubblier - but some of us remain determined to find out what crazy thing happens next, dramatized by some of the best actors on TV.
There is nothing more The Affair than these two getting together (and then inevitably falling apart in an epic catastrophe).
It's such an odd yet intriguing swerve, much in keeping with "The Affair's" willingness to mess around.
The drama, well scripted and beautifully acted as ever, continues to play around with time frames as we saw flashbacks to Vik's terminal cancer.

The original spark that came from Noah and Alison has fizzled out but there are still plenty of knotty relationships, zinging lines and even a larky cameo from Danish actor Claes Bang... This affair seems far from over.
The central character list might be a bit slimmer, but the suffering is still the same in The Affair's fifth and final season.
There's something insanely watchable about The Affair, tricks and all.
The Affair Season 5 Episode 1 was a colossal waste of time.
Cringeworthy: that is the only descriptor for the events that transpire throughout this episode.

In a perfect world, this show would have run a tight three seasons, but on a network that has a tendency to run its shows long past its expiration date, The Affair has thankfully been allowed to end on its own terms and not overstay its welcome.

I'd probably follow these characters (even Whitney) for an indefinite number of seasons - partly because of the sucker that I am, but also because "The Affair" can never be completely considered down for the count.
Tierney's performance as Helen is what really anchors this season and makes it as watchable as it is.
"The Affair" began at the "End" - Montauk - five seasons ago, and ends at The End. This seems exactly right.

The Affair has always been a fascinating show to watch because much like its characters, it has never feared following its instincts down the wildest paths possible, even if those instincts lead to some terrible choices.
Queer as Folk always felt dangerous and interesting, as if we were peeking in on a world we shouldn’t. The reboot feels jaded, as if we are watching things we’ve seen a hundred times before.
It adds up to a warm, intricate, humane portrait of a world in which people are finding their feet and their chosen families, all on constantly shifting sands. It’s good to have the folk back.
Somehow, Queer As Folk finds ever more delicious and delirious ways of offering prickly story beats and character arcs that refuse to flatten or homogenize the LGBTQ+ community.
It may be trash TV, but it’s OUR trash TV, and that makes all the difference.
Ultimately the new Queer as Folk, by telling a wider and more disparate set of stories, manages to produce a narrative that's broader and deeper — and significantly queerer — than its predecessors.

There’s plenty of emoting going on, and the issues at stake are clear enough, but there’s not enough character depth and warmth in the air. The characters seem self-absorbed, and, alas, their romantic histrionics and struggles didn’t move me.
Queer as Folk returns, with new characters caught up in the aftermath of a mass shooting. Trauma, romance, betrayal, and a lot of sex ensue in a proudly diverse, reimagined show.

Peacock’s iteration of the British 1999-2000 series Queer as Folk proves itself a pretty good queer soap if you can tolerate how self-absorbed, narcissistic and generally unlikeable most of the characters are.
Some viewers will find the thoughtless Brodie and his sitcom shenanigans too grating, but the series’ thoughtfulness and its sense of joy, inclusion and community make it a real winner.

While there’s a lot of messiness in this new version of Queer As Folk, it also introduces an interesting new set of characters and examines how much things have changed and stayed the same for the LGBTQIA community.
Peacock’s Queer As Folk hits hard but feels needed. It’s not perfect, but that gives us much to discuss.

But it's Jesse James Keitel as a trans woman trying to navigate her relationship, motherhood, and her own desires that is the breakout performer. Keitel is truly mesmerizing to watch, as is the series!
A ripped-from-the-headlines premise may locate the new series in the white-hot center of modernity, but Dunn and company extract little insight from that aggressive timeliness.
Queer as Folk has an abrasive, punky insouciance that's charming, and some nicely calibrated performances; it has a taste for excess that's winningly brazen, when parcelled out.
It makes for gripping, sometimes solemn, sometimes irreverent and always sexy viewing.
A continually fun, moving, gripping ride and one of the most exciting shows on television.
Equal parts silly, sexy, serious and smart.
“Queer as Folk” rises to the occasion when it explores the bigger contemporary themes in the LGBTQ community, even when the show is tethered to some of the baggage of previous versions of the series.

Its a pretty classic whodunit, where everybodys a suspect and nobodys talking. By blending in teen drama  refreshingly not sanitized to satisfy network censors  it keeps things interesting while feeling comfortably familiar.
The conclusion will be a surprise, one assumes. But the getting there is, as they might say in French class, déjà vu.
Passionate fans of the YA novel this steamy teen series is based on will be glad to know the TV version's mostly faithful to the book and is well-made and arresting yet cliched and slow to start.
The production is glossy and the acting is mediocre, but the writing is solid, and it's all perfectly tailored to the streaming era.

While I do like that they're taking these different archetypes and stereotypes and making commentary on them, so far the story doesn't feel that different from other mysteries or teen dramas of the same genre.

The story, based on the wildly popular young-adult novel by Karen M. McManus, deftly tweaks its balance of suspicions to keep things interesting, but it's McKenna and Van Grootel who really pull focus.
One of Us Is Lying has potential and good actors. Restraint, however, continues to bog it down in the first three episodes.
What eludes One of Us Is Lying is some special spark to set it apart from all the other murder mysteries and teen dramas out there... some jagged edges to break up all its slick competence.
Filled with twists and turns that will keep those who haven't read the book guessing. The acting and writing is sub par, but does get better as it goes on.
When the series finally kicks into gear, Chucky possesses the exuberant, mean-spirited magic of the best of the franchise.

Chucky manages to perfectly balance building on the franchises past with a clear eye to the future. This show is playing the hits while also experimenting and pushing itself into new and fresh directions.
What's really surprising is the naturalness with which the series develops the sincere scenes of [Devon and Arthur] falling in love. [Full review in Spanish]
Chucky works rather well, with the doll coming first to embody then pervert Jake's wholly reasonable desire for revenge on his tormentors.
Deliver something much more thoughtful than its gory veneer lets on.
All told, Chucky's campy mix of satire and slaughter has the potential to draw in new fans while expanding on the Child's Play cinematic universe in ways that longtime fans will surely enjoy.
In general there's a surprising depth and a willingness to grow beyond slasher stereotypes, here. Chucky not only acts as a love letter to the franchise, but moves it forward into the modern age.
These script "gimmicks" feel insufficient to re-launch a product that is perceived as exhausted. [Full review in Spanish]
Ultimately, there are better, scarier things you can be watching than Chucky.
It overall remains true to the tone of the movies that preceded it, and this jump to the small screen hasn't dulled Chucky's edge.
Chucky is a delight; a warped, wise, funny and very droll series with bits of gore thrown in, but nothing gory enough to hurt your head. It's a rigorous reinvention.
This is a solid start to Chucky's latest venture, promising all of the high-camp thrills and spills we associate with the horror icon.
As it unfolds, Chucky offers up some new toybox treasures for fans of the franchise.
It won't win over many new converts, but anyone with a soft spot for the cheery maniac doll will no doubt get a kick out of his latest reign of terror.
Chucky is a fun character-driven horror show that asks the question: what would happen if a killer doll showed up to that pool party scene in Bo Burnham's Eighth Grade?
Chucky is scary once again, and I can't wait to see what havoc he unleashes.
Chucky adds some fun story elements to the "murdering doll" dynamic, bringing the franchise back to it's earliest days.
Fit neatly into the Child's Play series as both a perfect onboarding point for new fans, and a breath of fresh air for series veterans.
Chucky is a richer, more personal experience - and yet as frightening as ever.

It's scary, it's funny, it's a little campy. We have this new fresh middle school setting and we're telling this new story while also still [...] learning more about this history and legacy of this entire franchise.
A strong start to the next chapter in this illustrious franchise that touches on some deeper issues.

I was also thrilled with how well Mancini balanced out the nods to the Chucky-verse but also creates this new story at the same time, and there are even some other homages to other horror properties as well.
Tonally, the series picks up the black comedy from its predecessors, and that's not a bad thing. The glaring issue was in some of the dialogue, however.
Chucky, the new series premiering on Syfy, retains all of the character's penchant for grotesque kills and juvenile, acidic humor... Elegant, this show is not.
Brad Dourif's voice work has always been what makes the character so distinctive and, at times, extremely funny, so the actor's inclusion here pays big dividends.
For all of its blood-soaked mayhem, though, it's also worth noting that Chucky is surprisingly warm in terms of its atmosphere and direction.

Chucky is a fine attempt at bringing the killer doll to the small screen. The allure of Brad Dourif as the evil doll is enough to lure me back. But if you aren't familiar with the Child's Play franchise, don't start with Chucky.
There's only one vaguely interesting formula tweak here and it's Mancini's decision to make his protagonist queer and then to handle it with a refreshingly casual sensitivity.
Honestly, anybody tuning in to Chucky is there for the doll. In that respect, the series delivers solidly.
With a start this strong, Chucky has found a new home on television. I can easily see being this show's friend to the end.
While you won't have to worry about sleeping with the light on, the premiere is an effective, witty next step for the worst "Good Guy" ever.
Horror franchises come and go, but Chucky is forever.
Fans of Mancini's films will find plenty to like about Chucky, although the four episodes available for review are also accessible for new viewers.
Chucky walks a fascinating tonal tightrope as a funny, absurd series that engenders sympathy as well as shock.
Offers an admirably different perspective for a horror franchise -- but viewers will need to buy into the teen drama to appreciate this iteration of Chucky.
Despite an impressive supporting cast that includes Josh Duhamel and Judy Greer, it’s Zellweger who very much ensures the spotlight stays on her.
Renée Zellwegers award-worthy performance, shes almost unrecognizable as Pam Hupp--which makes the series watchable.
This series is a frustrating and surprisingly boring attempt to cash in on the true crime boom.
The thing about Pam, sadly, is that despite her crimes, she’s not all that interesting.
The Thing About Pam has some serious tonal issues, but it’s not without some merit. Zellwegger is good, the prosthetic notwithstanding, and Fleshler is an outstanding character actor.

Maybe it’s a good thing to be so unmoored by a TV show. For better or worse, that destabilization, that determined desire for clarity on what this show is, will keep me watching. Yet another one of The Thing About Pam’s surprises.
Renée Zellweger transforms in this darkly funny true-crime series.

Hats off to Renée Zellweger to go all out in portraying the frumpily sinister Pam Hupp. Not only is it a more accurate representation of its suburban Midwest setting, it’s far more entertaining than any number of sleek, coastal Nicole Kidman cable series.
Overall, The Thing About Pam feels lackluster and gaudy, with zero care for the victims and treatment of Pam as if she’s a celebrity for a good reason.
The flourishes used on The Thing About Pam were tiring us out by the end of the first episode; we can’t imagine how exhausted we’ll feel after watching the entire six-episode season.

The Thing About Pam stars Zellweger as another monster and she brings an equal amount of vinegary exuberance to the work. But instead of playing a fantasy figure of cold depravity, she’s playing a real person.

While providing superficial nods to Pam’s grievances, The Thing About Pam repeatedly recedes into a one-note character study, a regression only emphasized by Renée Zellweger’s exaggerated lead performance.
It’d be a shame if Zellweger’s first acting gig after her Oscar-boosted return to Hollywood were, ultimately, little more than NBC cross-promotion.
Even over six episodes, this series is far too long and not worth the effort that Renee Zellweger puts into playing the title character.
It's a true-crime experiment that clearly wants to be the next Fargo and doesn't get there.
The Thing About Pam does an impressive job of translating an addictive tale to the small screen.
A watchable if often underwhelming true crime docudrama that wants to both be weird and play it safe, ending up in a strange middle ground between the two.

Zellweger is simultaneously broadly cartoonish and blandly nonspecific. She squints so much that her eyes lose whatever interiority they might have reflected; there is no real difference between her smile or her frown.
There’s a lot of blurriness of intention around the storytelling in The Thing About Pam and an ultimately complacent belief that Renée Zellweger slurping on soda is enough to count as Emmy bait.

Zellweger, in her biggest TV role so far, looks like she is thoroughly enjoying her time as this larger-than-life character, whose boldness knew no end until she was finally made to face the consequences of her crime streak.

When the Coen Brothers-inspired tone works, it's deliciously satisfying. But then you remember that this entertainingly stranger-than-fiction story wouldn't exist if innocent people hadn't died, and you feel little queasy.
The Thing About Pam offers an intriguing but tonally off-putting rehash of a familiar true crime story.
Even if you've never watched Dateline NBC -- but more especially if you have -- NBC's miniseries The Thing About Pam is irresistibly entertaining.
Its purpose, generally, is to keep things reassuringly intimate, and above the fray. Such things aside, all in all this is a wholly compelling tale.
With its zippy tone of cocked-eyebrow camp, the limited NBC series about convicted murderer Pam Hupp is a welcome departure from the current avalanche of poker-faced true-crime efforts.
In its 2022 iteration, Bel-Air capitalizes on the two things dominating television today: nitty-gritty realism, and nostalgia.
The missing element here is the camp of a juicy soap. If we can’t laugh, then we should gasp. Remaking an iconic series is a silly endeavor—why not lean all the way into that?
Bel-Air is enjoyable enough as a dramatic reboot of the popular '90s sitcom starring Will Smith.
While the symbolism may sometimes be laid on a little thick, Cooper demonstrates early that he isn’t afraid to tackle thought-provoking social debates.
Like the original, it gets by on the charm of its lead, the immediate distaste for Carlton, and the warmth and loveliness of Aunt Viv (if Cassandra Freeman is recast, there will be hell to pay).
With a two-season order and the promise of curiosity from an audience looking to write this off, Bel-Air is likely to catch many off guard.
Painfully earnest and mostly stripped of its original buoyancy, this formerly amusing and entertaining fish-out-of-water story is left gasping for an original thought.
There’s a lot at play, addressing issues of race, wealth, class, striving for the American Dream, and then getting it for good or ill. This is a dark take, and reflective of the times.
All the humour, warmth and character of the original has been sucked out and replaced with... nothing, really.
The shift from comedy to drama and 90’s to modern day is jarring at times, but the performances are compelling. There’s something here -- hopefully they figure out exactly what.
Whether this all adds up to something is hard to say at this juncture, but its definitely worth sticking around to find out.
Despite the more serious tone, the show still has heart.
Peacock’s reimagining of the ’90s sitcom goes over the top with drama, conflict and heavy-handed symbolism.
Bel-Air has the potential to truly stand on its own if it doesn’t try to be to cute with its ties to The Fresh Prince. From what we’ve seen in the first episode, it’s well on its way to doing that.
The main Banks making the series work is Jabari, the newcomer playing the fictional Will Smith. He has a lively swagger that emerges more readily as the series goes on.
This show sits comfortably at the intersection of nostalgia, drama and Blackness. Out of the remakes that continue to flood your streaming networks, Bel-Air is the one you should be watching.
Overall “Bel-Air” is its own, surprisingly engaging production. What it does have fully in common with its predecessor is that even as it remains entertaining, it still has much more to say.
Once upon a time, Will from west Philly was miles from home, but the show he was in knew exactly what it was and where it was going. Bel-Air finds that a difficult trick to replicate.

Suck all the joy, exuberance and wondrous charisma out of “The Fresh Prince” — a worthy launchpad for an actor who, in his prime, was widely considered the biggest movie star in the world — and you’re left with the gloomy and plodding “Bel-Air.”
This series has a long way to go before it earns its crown.
Bel-Air strives for authenticity in the most thinly drawn manner possible.
Morgan Cooper has successfully translated his short viral video into an interesting series, but Bel-Air needs to differentiate itself a bit more or it risks becoming a spoof of itself.
The series has the acting talent to be its own thing, but it feels a bit unfair to burden the ensemble so overwhelmingly with those who played them before.
The opening episodes establish a catchy beat, with the main question being how long they can sustain it.

Fantastic update that works on two levels - nostalgia for the original sitcom while also a great soap opera in the vein of another 90s hit, Beverly Hills 90210.  Also very topical without being preachy. Will vs Carlton is the biggest change, but it works.
Its interesting how well Bel-Air remixes and plays around with what we know. The characters never feel unfamiliar but theyre also different enough to be an interesting watch.

The inverted tone sets up a strong case for the reboot's very existence, deconstructing the veneer of '90s nostalgia for a more honest examination of class warfare within Black communities, and how they differ so greatly from coast to coast.
There are no weak spots in the cast; everyone brings the right authority to their role. Most crucial of course is newcomer Banks, an excellent selection.

A confusing series that's too tied to its sitcom roots to pass for a drama to take seriously. It's unclear with its intentions and doesn't justify its existence other than to underline a new era of streaming that's starved for content.
Bel-Air is a glossy, expensive-looking soap that, like Fox’s Our Kind of People, puts the spotlight on uber-wealthy Black families. But “fresh?” Not so much.
Bel-Air is an inspiring reflection of the interconnected power and joy-based resilience that is Black America.
If the writing can lean into the characters and let them breathe, Bel-Air will work.
Do we really need a cool Carlton, a sexy Uncle Phil, or a sad Will?
This reboot is thoughtfully and delicately filling in the gaps that its precursor, a ’90s network sitcom created by two white writers, left behind.
Peacock’s reimagining of The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air is darker, more dramatic, and surprisingly compelling.
Even without it looking back, Bel-Air’s slick confidence makes it a compelling series in its own right.

It’s one thing to ask whether it would be great if the Fresh Prince premise was used in service of a grittier, more dramatic take on the story; it’s another to make that twist work over the long haul.

The scriptwriting has to be superb, and too often here, things fall flat -- plot lines are too predictable, character motivations are slightly questionable, and the dialogue can be a bit too expositional.
The dialogue can sound stiff, and constant references to both the original show and Cooper’s video get tiresome. Yet it does have all the makings of a solid drama.
A bold reimagining that maintains the essence of the original show while exploring important social themes from an authentic, Black perspective.
In an era of countless reboots and revivals that we didn’t ask for nor wish to see, Bel-Air truly stands out among the crowd.
[It works] whether or not you’ve seen ”Fresh Prince.” In fact, it might be even better if you haven’t.
It takes every aspect of the original show and sucks out the joy.
The genre shift means that Banks can’t rely on broadness to win the audience over; luckily, his performance hits the right shade of every emotion he needs to play, from top to bottom.
It’s probably the most 2022 thing imaginable to take one adored show and reboot it in a way that feels derivative of at least a half-dozen other shows.
This new take bucks the odds and plays for audiences new and old, proving the resilience of a premise that works even when the approach is “flipped turned upside down.”
It has many of the familiar tropes of 21st-century teen drama, and none is used to particularly gripping effect: the petty sexual jealousies and earnest melodrama quickly start to grate.

It's really well-crafted. I mean, it's well-written. The production is lavish. The costumes are amazing. Watching these episodes, you're kind of transported back to a time with a lot of turning points for modern society.
Downton Abbey isn't trying to change the face of television, so let's just enjoy the loveliness while it lasts.
he nation will no doubt be grateful to see its favourite escapist fantasy deigning to engage with our piffling contemporary anxieties.
The acting. The set design. The costumes. The sharp writing. The attention to detail. All of it came together in a way that made this show more than just another period drama.
Certainly Downton had its soapy moments. But for most fans, I don't think this was the series' chief appeal. Rather, it was the moments of kindness.

The Earl of Grantham having made a tectonic plate shift in his mind set over a myriad of matters. He's up to speed with the changes of the century, but are the fans, as we prepare to say our final good byes?

While the upcoming season is uneven -- there are a few awfully wobbly moments in the saggy middle hours -- the series is well on its way to going out in a manner that will have its fans sweetening their cups of tea with salty tears.

Downton Abbey may strike some as an unbearably fussy and silly affair, but it has also fully and richly answered that little boy's question: They lived that way out of a sense of duty. And while it lasted, wasn't it grand?
What seems clear, as Downton strolls toward the finish line, is that the show's influence will reverberate well beyond its five-year run.
It isn't a spoiler to point out that what was true from the beginning holds true now: creator Julian Fellowes seems to love these characters and he seems determined to do right by them.
Even though it was feeling a bit threadbare in recent years, its classy departure is likely to leave its legions of fans pining for more. Golly gumdrops, what will we do without it?

Downton Abbey has always been television to luxuriate in, and its final season will delight fans with more of the same superb production quality and writing that makes the aristocratic Crawley family feel part of our own.
The final Downton season is satisfying, engaging and nostalgic. And if there is, at some point, a movie? You know we'll be watching.
The final season of the popular series with more changes than ever in store for the characters.
For a series dedicated to supposed historical realism, Downton Abbey wraps things up with a bow of pure fantasy.
The sixth and final season of the series delivers happy endings all around, as if rewarding viewers for their devotion to the lives of the wealthy and the service classes alike.
Even when the series drifts towards the boring or trite, its exemplary cast and the endearing characters they play are enough to hold our attention.
Our love for the characters enables us to overlook the vexing problems in the script.
The characterizations are beginning to get cartoonish.

An air of change and the sense of an era ending threads through the first episode... a terrific hour that winds up several long-running stories while stoking a few new ones as the series marks its final run of episodes.
Beautiful, elegant final ride, full of love and nostalgia and joy. The only way to go...

The [first] episode ends with a coming-together that will delight the show's die-hard fans - and help carry the rest of us through the overly sentimental reunions, unlikely outbursts, kidnappings and, yes, sudden deaths.

Downton simply continues its sharp observations of human behavior among fundamentally decent people, as animated by some of the loveliest faces, voices, and cinematography on the tube, it still has much to offer.
Suffice to say, Fellowes steams ahead as a quality purveyor of British confectionary.
A proper ending for a unique and memorable ensemble drama that has had a few ups and downs over the years.
For a series set almost 100 years ago, the storylines were surprisingly relevant today.
It's loop-the-loop loopy, but also exciting; the fun Fellowes is having is infectious.
The season is best when it attends to the fears and fury of those in the underclass at risk of becoming even more marginalized by social flux.
Despite the sadness over the end of our Downton addiction, please try to enjoy this great last season ... It's the best one yet, with many happy and sad revelations.
The year is 1925 and the times they are a-changin' - and creator Julian Fellowes really wants to make sure you know that.
Fellowes hints at drama and pulls his punches.

I'm happy to report (without any spoilers) that it remains what it has been for years - a pretty melodrama, whose characters we've come to know well, grounded in a thought-provoking historical moment.
Rossum is utterly captivating, finding nuance in a character who’s an icon — even if it’s only in her mind.
Like the Los Angeles billboard icon at the heart of it, the unconventional bioseries is whatever you want it to be—and Emmy Rossum is acting her heart off...
Maybe Angelyne is an idol made of plastic. But what’s so great about authenticity?
The approach is mockumentary style, however it isn't mocking its subject -- respect is shown and her positive light is celebrated.
Features an entertaining, lively performance by an almost unrecognizable Emmy Rossum in the title role.
This is a vibrant series that’s more interested in the stories that people tell themselves than it is in cold hard facts. And in its own way, that’s the most truthful way to look at someone’s life.
The storytelling of Angelyne leaves a lot to be desired, but Rossum’s performance cuts through the script gymnastics...
Anchored by a superb leading performance and a deft understanding of what its subject represents, Angelyne is a must-watch for Angelenos and celebrity novices alike.

If anything, Angelyne commits to the work of humanizing formerly maligned sex symbols beyond the surface level. If the largest sex organ is truly the brain, both Angelyne the series and Angelyne, the woman, know that.
Angelyne approximates its subject in the wrong ways: It's big, attention-getting and has all the depth of a billboard.
Actress Emmy Rossum is clearly having a blast portraying the various chapters of the enigmatic woman’s life story, but she tempers the performance from devolving into the cartoonish.
Thanks in large part to Rossum’s deeply sympathetic and almost protective performance, “Angelyne” turns Angelyne into the kind of star she always wanted to be.
I liked “Angelyne” better as it went on... without ever being wholly convinced that it was a trip I needed to take.
Where Angelyne most succeeds, however, is when it echoes the same carefully constructed campiness of its subject rather than try to create gravitas from the ground up.

With the entire five-episode run premiering at once, audiences can binge this funny, weird, and touching story that turns an iconic pin-up into an icon. This is a very entertaining tale that has more depth than I ever expected.
Rarely makes for more than a fitfully engrossing watch.

Rossum and her masterful team of collaborators fully understood the assignment, and created an immersive experience that is equal parts fun, tragic, magical, offbeat, and just as unique as its subject.
All these different layers of evasiveness, kaleidoscopic perspectives, and slivers of self-mythology feel like what Angelyne might have wanted.
Angelyne makes merry play of the lines between identity and delusion, and does it with all the bubbly verve of the real-life figure it’s digging at. It’s brilliant stuff.
Angelyne doesn’t debunk every myth about the local legend; no series ever could. But this technicolor portrait of Hollywood’s sweet-yet-spicy hometown hero offers something almost better.
There's an endearing level of protectiveness in Rossum's performance, and indeed the entire production. 'Angelyne' is funny, but Angelyne is never the butt of the joke.

[Spicer and Tcherniak] can’t always build momentum in the series’ sluggish openers, but as the series gets loopier, with sci-fi elements and Brechtian theatrical pastiche, they hold the mish-mash between drama, comedy and anything-goes together.
It's easy to slide through and laugh along with the sitcom's snake-filled first season in one sitting, and to buy everything it's pitching.
Though just a touch above a middling comedy, viewers will have a few laughs and might also learn a bit about the phenomenon of "banking while Black..."

The best of them is Killing It has Craig Robinson as a guy who decides to become a snake hunter in Florida. Better than his last sitcom try, NBC’s Mr. Robinson, this one is raunchier, since it’s not on a network.

Killing It gets off to a rough but promising start, thanks to a fun performance from Robinson, with an assist from O’Doherty. We hope that as the story gets more personal, the characters will outshine the gags.
Unfortunately, [Killing It] is no Brooklyn Nine-Nine. It doesn’t have the snap, crackle and pop in the dialogue, the density of gags, the brilliantly drawn characters or the magic casting.
At a meta level, every episode feels like a satirical exploration of some different aspect of life in modern America.
Tossing out society’s expectation of kindness, camaraderie, and citizenship is a dark path that also creates narrative possibility, and Killing It slithers steadily upon it.
Killing It‘s comedy only rarely rises to laugh-out-loud levels of hilarity, but the odd-couple dynamic between Jillian and Craig makes for a breezy ride.
This might be the season where everyone finally exiles Mickey, realizing that he's pure poison.
If this elegiac season has been about what's been lost, it's also been about how trauma and tragedy will never truly stay buried.
This is not how I imagined The Fall concluding... It's both futile and poetic, I suppose. And surprising -- I'll give creator and executive producer Allan Cubitt that.
This year's series has been the natural conclusion of the race to the bottom.
Cubitt has found more to explore; perhaps six episodes is stretching it too far, but Anderson's magnificent, controlled performance is worth tuning in for again and again.
A worthy send off for the series.
The Fall needed an actor who could play charming and wicked with equal panache, who could hold his own against Gillian Anderson. For all his talents, Dornan is not that actor.
If Season 3 is the last season of Netflix's The Fall, it went out on a strange note.
For all its psychological, almost literary complexity, it loses much of its narrative steam. It's that great 21st-century phenomenon: a show that's more fun to think about than it is to watch.
This show thinks it is Very Important Viewing, unmissable drama, televisual literature. The fact is it's very missable indeed.
Season 3 does a passable job ending the story, but you have to watch the other seasons first.

The Fall was back for another bout of sadistic psychological chess played out between Jamie Dornan and Gillian Anderson, subjecting viewers to its usual unbearable tension but in the opposite way we expected.

Between the spurts of sparse dialogue, dragged-out shots of dimly-lit rooms and corridors (a regrettable legacy of Scandi noir), and long periods of staring into space, there was enough padding here to insulate an attic.
The atmosphere is stiflingly tense.
Worth a watch for viewers familiar with the series.
It's a frustrating end to a frustrating season.
When it's firing on all cylinders, though, the third season of The Fall is an unusually meditative, self-possessed piece of television, one that actually earns the "psychological thriller" title.
What was hard to watch became unworthy in Season 3, and that's a fall we simply can't bear.
There is a fantasy here, an almost-misandrist one in the best possible sense.
This is The Fall, which doesn't squander opportunities to show off its mastery of the slow burn.
Allan Cubitt certainly knows how to hook an audience.
As good as Anderson is throughout, her Stella suffers from a Season 3 lack of development -- we learn nothing about her in this new season that we did not know from the previous two.
Mr. Cubitt's unconventional methods mix standard police thriller elements of detection and chase with long, quiet scenes of conversation, interrogation and surveillance.

Its hallmark traits of knife-edge tension, sexual discussion and psychologically-charged scenes have been posted missing, and replaced with an hour of medical procedures and jargon that would bore the most ardent of E.R. fans.
Well-written with some inspired production design and a great ensemble cast, I consider Battlestar Galactica one of the best sci-fi television series ever
The last ten episodes of Battlestar Galactica deliver plenty of puzzles, prophecies and dreams; answer questions and raise others; and pay off characters in satisfying and usually surprising ways.
There are certainly a number of issues that continue to haunt the show, but the story is infinitely fascinating regardless and we can't wait to see how things play out.

The mutiny storyline was the highlight of the season, which overall had an unusual number of highs and lows - there were very strong episodes and storylines throughout, but usually some noteworthy weaker elements would also show up along the way.
With a renewed sense of purpose and enthusiasm season four is more cohesive and creatively invigorating than the third installment of the series, which often felt disjointed and needlessly didactic.

This final season of BSG surely contains many faults, most of which are the direct result of mysteries the show had imposed on itself. But when it comes time to send off the crew of Galactica, it is done in the small moments, just as it should be.
It's a relief to have the series back to pick up a strange, uneven TV season.
The return of Battlestar Galactica reminds us why it's so often considered one of the best shows on television.

Most of what's in these ten episodes seems designed to get your hopes up even while the showrunners are busy dashing them, and perhaps most noticeable is the fact that the show has become more depressing and fatalistic than ever.

There was some disappointment, yes, but god damned the episode was absolutely breathtaking. On the whole, it was a relatively worthy conclusion to a groundbreaking series, albeit with a manipulative coda.

After anxious months of geeky Web speculation over how Battlestar's final season will conclude, the best thing about "He That Believeth in Me" was how it bypassed our feverish expectations and instead set up new central conflicts.
The series continues to transcend the sci-fi genre and bring out real emotions, social issues and conflict.

And even though this particular episode may not have been able to clear the yawning chasm of our expectations, it was an appropriate conclusion to one of the most poignant, smart and relevant television shows of the last decade.
I don't mean to sound flippant. I kind of like the audacity of a sci-fi series getting this explicitly spiritual in explaining its mythology.
For a series that had always used familiar trappings of sci-fi like robots and spaceships to comment on our present-day circumstances, it was the perfect final sequence.
Tonight's Battlestar Galactica finale was a cop out, but it was also the perfect goodbye. Ron Moore dropped the ball on plot but as always, the show delivered where it really mattered.
So, overall, I was fully satisfied with the ending, and I don't feel like I wasted four seasons of televisions.
Tonight's episode is superb, and barrels - relentlessly - toward the answers.

To be honest, I'm weary of Baltar and his endless visions/hallucinations, as I am of the fleet's wandering as the surviving colonists try, somewhat fitfully, to find their way back to a home planet none of them remembers.
Season Four, broadcast in two chunks with a climbing-the-wall break due to the writers' strike, proved the most challenging, soul-searching and devastatingly turbulent yet.

The thing with shows such as BSG and the brilliant cop drama The Wire is that they set the bar so high in terms of sheer entertainment, that it is almost impossible for them to consistently deliver the levels of excellence we've greedily come to expect.

Yes there were missteps, but this will be remembered as a show delivering compelling, emotional moments in nearly every episode, along with some of the most layered and thought-provoking situations and characters you'd find on television.
I HAVE NEVER IN MY LIFE YELLED AT A SHOW LIKE THIS. I WAS ROOTING FOR YOU. WE WERE ALL ROOTING FOR YOU! HOW DARE YOU!
There is no doubt that the tour-de-force performance of Edward James Olmos as Admiral William Adama will rank among the best heroes in TV history.

Much has been made of the show's embrace of major social themes and plot points that recalled current events, but it also combined a heady brew of pulp fiction, religious mysticism and solid character drama.
A lot of basic and mundane things don't add up for me.

My take on the Battlestar Galactica series finale was that it was 99% incredibly satisfying and delivered beyond what I was hoping for. In the end, it seems destiny will be what it will be, much like fighting gravity.
Somehow, out of all the doom and gloom, death, destruction and nihilism we've had, Battlestar Galactica finished with something approaching a happy ending.
Battlestar is never more enjoyable than when Mary McDonnell's President Laura Roslin is spouting this stuff to a dubious but smitten Adama.
Battlestar Galactica remains the best drama nobody seems to be watching.
The action has enough flavor to make clear what's at stake with the personal dramas.
Even if you're skeptical of science fiction, "Battlestar Galactica" will make a true believer out of you.
The dilemmas on the drama have many parallels in the real world.
It is to the Sci Fi Channel what "The Sopranos" is to HBO, a show that defied all expectations and became that rarest of beasts: a big, fat hit with a cult following.
Battlestar Galatica has defied the odds.
Jumping back for its last batch of episodes, "Battlestar Galactica" continues its improbable ascent from a mediocre 1970s footnote to one of the more intriguing episodic hours of the 21st century.
The multitude of exegeses and theories devoted to major plot twists and minor details attest to the series's enduring egghead appeal.
Riveting as ever, "Battlestar Galactica" proves again that sci fi doesn't have to be clap trap.

Buddy, your show's been on for 12 seasons. Don't you want to send off your characters in any type of meaningful way? Nah. Let's just use the time to get back at someone for something people have long forgotten about.
Two and Half Men hit a new low every season and then continued to sink even further underground. During this last season, the show went off the rails in terms of absurdity and offensiveness.
May not have been great art, but it was an amusingly self-conscious conclusion built around an unfulfilled promise that at least punished the principals responsible for that unfulfilled promise.

Was it appropriate? Classy? I just know I laughed. Great TV or no, Two and a Half Men ended its many lucrative years in a way true to its nature: going for the punchlines, laughing at death, as expensive objects rained from the sky.
Was that the sound of a piano crashing down on the hopes and dreams of 10 million fans?
So really, was Two and a Half Men just a regular sitcom, or was it the greatest episode of Black Mirror ever about a bunch of actors stuck forever inside a sitcom of hell.
A big, crude and unapologetically vulgar finale. In other words, it ended the only way it knew how.
Just say "goodbye" and leave the "good riddance" to Sheen.
Whether you liked the finale or not, the show doesn't care. It, and Chuck Lorre, went out on the exact notes it wanted to end. And that note, as far as Lorre was concerned, was a #winning one.
Seemingly designed less to provide closure than as an extended rejoinder to those who have criticized "Men" through the years.
I swear to God, I don't think I could come up with a worse ending.
Two and a Half Men has always been a sturdy little sitcom.
Resident Alien is still a hoot, and I’m digging the current “Harry in New York City” storyline. But the show isn’t perfect, and some of the human subplots have been lacking ...
Resident Alien's strength lies with its ability to develop characters. It's a rarity among comedies to have so many fully-fleshed characters you wholeheartedly support.
It's still amusing, but the premiere didn't contain the laugh-out-loud scenes of early Season 1 episodes.
This season brings in more heart, humor, and drama. Alan Tudyk somehow got even better in this role, which felt impossible after season 1.
Wolf Like Me aims high, but ends up howling at the moon with some deeply implausible parental angst
Wolf Like Me might claim to be a TV show, but its really a movie. (A short one, at that.)
Wolf Like Me is right up there with the likes of Russian Doll for just smart and fun storytelling that brings the surreal into the very real.
The first three episodes mildly intrigued me – but not enough to want to continue.
Before things take a supernatural turn, they play out like an afternoon Hallmark Channel weepie.
So bad it's good? No, just the former...
Is it a love story? A story about redemtion? About creating a trusting, loving family after tragedy has visited the home? It's hard to know what's really going on here, or why it's going on.
Isla Fisher's performance alone is worth the price of admission.
Wolf Like Me might just be the unexpected viewing highlight of your summer.
The show is, in a way, about magic – and to make that click, it needs to have its own magic. Gad and Fisher bring it. There’s a playfulness here that gives it energy.
Wolf Like Me takes its traumatic situation so seriously I kept waiting for it to let its hair down.
The six-episode series is so charming, disarming and odd it's almost a work of magic. And, as with any magic trick, the delight depends on not knowing how it's going to work.
Wolf Like Me is a delightful surprise. As as monster love story that resonates with genuine emotion and sharp psychology, it plays against type by being a drama first and foremost.
The show is heavy handed [...] without actually delivering
It has a true bleeding heart, gushier than a lot of other rom-coms, but it could use a lot more bite.

Wolf Like Me is more drama than comedy, but it works either way, despite its strange premise. Much of that is thanks to Gad and Fisher, but it's also because Forsythe has ground the show's more supernatural elements in reality.
Held up next to others of its kind, Wolf Like Me may not do enough to cement itself in memory, but it's an unexpectedly heartfelt tale...

While I won't spoil the twist for you here, let's just say that it works because Wolf Like Me never tries to be a genre bait-and-switch but rather uses elements from multiple types of stories to deliver a satisfying narrative.
A show that takes a moment to pin down, but feels wonderfully richer the deeper you go.
Fisher's always possessed the talent of a leading lady in projects like The Great Gatsby and Arrested Development. Here, she plays up a tender heart hiding behind wall of quick-witted jokes.
Whether you want to find Wolf Like Me utterly serious or likably silly, it's all there in [Fisher's] performance, which made me laugh and tear up in equal measure.
...Abe Forsythe brings the same brand of humor to the series as he did to Little Monsters.
Wolf Like Me's supernatural elements are its weakest parts, delivered in wispy terms that make them indistinct and generic.
"Wolf Like Me" is more of a bummer than a fun watch.

While the first two episodes require a healthy dose of patience, it's worth holding on for the remaining four, where the show stops relying on mystery and the two main characters lay it all on the line, for the audience and each other.
The Cord was crazy and unpredictable and emotional, and gave audiences one of the series' creepiest moments in the past/present juxtaposition
It was all creepy as hell, but it was an 'aww' kind of creepy. The creepiest creepy 'aww' ever, but still we can't help but say it. Aww. Rest in peace, Norman.
